member.summary: The dependency list in order

member.name: M:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Smo.DependencyObjects.#ctor
member.summary: Constructor

member.name: M:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Smo.DependencyObjects.Add(Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Smo.SqlSmoObject,Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Smo.SqlSmoObject)
member.summary: Add a new tuple relation of a parent node and its child node which depends on it. A node can be added multiple times as a parent, child or single node in successive calls.
member.param: The parent node of the dependent child node.
The child node dependent on the existence of the parent node.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Smo.DependencyObjects.Add(Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Smo.SqlSmoObject)
member.summary: Add a new single node with no relation to either a parent or child node. A node can be added multiple times as a parent, child or single node in successive calls.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Smo.DependencyObjects.Clear
member.summary: Clear the internal state to be reused.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Smo.DependencyObjects.GetDependencies
member.summary: Return the list of dependencies such that each node is guaranteed to depend on no more than the preceding nodes (if any). The ancestor and child lists could be returned with each node but it currently isn't needed. This can be called as many times as you want with node tuples being added as well. If you want to start over completely, call Clear().
member.returns: The List of SqlSmoObjects in dependency order.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Smo.DependencyObjects.StartNode
member.summary: Get a valid starting node for a dependency descent until there are no more valid candidates (signifying we are done).
member.returns: A valid SqlSmoObject, or null if no more valid root nodes are left to process.

member.summary: Constructor

member.summary: SMO Type being pre-fetched

member.name: T:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Smo.Prefetch
member.summary:
This class is responsible for batching prefetching of SMO objects for Database scripting.
The class takes a list of URNs produced by Transfer.GetObjects and while enumerating through URNs looks ahead for URNs of the same type, groups them together in batches of manageable size and pre-fetches all needed objects in memory. It's functionality currently overlaps with functionality of Transfer, however it does prefetching in a more optimal way that ensures that memory consumption never goes too high.
At the moment it isn't used directly from Transfer class. The only user of this class is Generate Script Wizard.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Smo.Prefetch.#ctor(Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Smo.Database,Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Smo.ScriptingOptions)
member.summary: Constructor

member.name: M:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Smo.Prefetch.EnumerateObjectUrns(System.Collections.Generic.IList{Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Sdk.Sfc.Urn})
member.summary: Enumerates Urns while prefetching corresponsing portions of the database into memory Most of the types gets prefetched entirely when they first appear in the list Tables and Views are further sub-divided into batches, typically 5000 objects at a time This function purges a previous batch before bringing into memory - this is done to cap the total memory consumption.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Smo.Prefetch.CreateBatchBlock(System.String)
member.summary: Factory method for creating prefetch blocks

member.summary: Current Database

member.summary: Current Server

member.summary: Current Scripting Options

member.name: M:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Smo.Prefetch.UrnIterator.BuildBatchBlocks
member.summary: This function builds batch blocks.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Smo.Prefetch.UrnIterator.TryGetBatchBlock(System.String,Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Smo.BatchBlock@)
member.summary: Search for the last batch block with matching type name. Use that block only when the schema matches too.

member.name: T:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Smo.BatchBlock
member.summary: Each batch block contains enough information to prefetch a batch of SMO objects. Due to implementation all objects in the same batch must share the same type and schema - only object name can vary.

member.name: T:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Smo.LimitedBatchBlock
member.summary: This class represents a batch block used to load Tables, Views, Stored Procedures, etc The total number of objects in one batch is limited to a predefined constant - see MaximumObjectsPerBatch below Also due to implementation all objects must share the same schema. LimitedBatchBlock instances accumulate names and use them later when querying SMO objects

member.name: T:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Smo.UnlimitedBatchBlock
member.summary: This class represents an unlimited batch which is used to load all existing objects of a given type. It doesn't record individual names of objects and doesn't care about the total number of objects returned by a query

member.name: M:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Smo.RestoreOptions.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: P:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Smo.RestoreOptions.KeepReplication
member.summary: KEEP_REPLICATION KEEP_REPLICATION prevents replication settings from being removed when a database backup or log backup is restored on a warm standby server and the database is recovered.

member.name: P:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Smo.RestoreOptions.KeepTemporalRetention
member.summary: KEEP_TEMPORAL_RETENTION KEEP_TEMPORAL_RETENTION prevents temporal history tables retention policy setting from being removed when a database backup is restored on a warm standby server and the database is recovered.
member.value: true if [keep temporal retention]; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Smo.RestoreOptions.SetRestrictedUser
member.summary: RESTRICTED_USER Restricts access for the newly restored database to members of the db_owner, dbcreator, or sysadmin roles.
member.value: true if [set restricted user]; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Smo.RestoreOptions.ContinueAfterError
member.summary: CONTINUE_AFTER_ERROR Specifies that the restore operation is to continue after an error is encountered.
member.value: true if [continue after error]; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Smo.RestoreOptions.ClearSuspectPageTableAfterRestore
member.summary: Deletes entries in the suspect page table.
member.value: true if [clear suspect page table after restore]; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Smo.RestoreOptions.RecoveryState
member.value: true if [with no recovery]; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Smo.RestoreOptions.StandByFile
member.summary: STANDBY Undo uncommitted transactions, but save the undo actions in a standby file that allows the recovery effects to be reversed.
member.value: The recovery with stand by file.

member.name: P:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Smo.RestoreOptions.Blocksize
member.summary: BLOCKSIZE Specifies the physical block size, in bytes. The supported sizes are 512, 1024, 2048, 4096, 8192, 16384, 32768, and 65536 (64 KB) bytes. The default is 65536 for tape devices and 512 otherwise. If you are restoring a backup from a CD-ROM, specify BLOCKSIZE=2048.

member.name: P:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Smo.RestoreOptions.BufferCount
member.summary: BUFFERCOUNT Specifies the total number of I/O buffers to be used for the restore operation. Large numbers of buffers might cause "out of memory" errors because of inadequate virtual address space in the Sqlservr.exe process.

member.name: P:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Smo.RestoreOptions.MaxTransferSize
member.summary: MAXTRANSFERSIZE Specifies the largest unit of transfer in bytes to be used between the backup media and SQL Server. The possible values are multiples of 65536 bytes (64 KB) ranging up to 4194304 bytes (4 MB).
member.value: The size of the max transfer.

member.name: P:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Smo.RestoreOptions.ReplaceDatabase
member.summary: REPLACE Specifies that SQL Server should create the specified database and its related files even if another database already exists with the same name. In such a case, the existing database is deleted. When the REPLACE option is not specified, a safety check occurs. This prevents overwriting a different database by accident.

member.name: P:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Smo.RestoreOptions.PercentCompleteNotification
member.summary: Gets or sets the percentage interval for PercentCompleteEventHandler event handler calls for individual Restore Operations.

member.name: T:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Smo.DatabaseRecoveryState
member.summary: Database recovery state.

member.name: F:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Smo.DatabaseRecoveryState.WithRecovery
member.summary: RECOVERY Leave the database ready to use by rolling back uncommitted transactions. Additional transaction logs cannot be restored.

member.name: F:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Smo.DatabaseRecoveryState.WithNoRecovery
member.summary: NORECOVERY Instructs the restore operation to not roll back any uncommitted transactions for another transaction log backup to be restored later. The database remains in the restoring state after the restore operation.

member.name: F:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Smo.DatabaseRecoveryState.WithStandBy
member.summary: STANDBY Undo uncommitted transactions, but save the undo actions in a standby file that allows the recovery effects to be reversed.
